p: Rhododendron tomentosum Harmaja (previously entitled by several different names [ 1], most frequently Ledum palustre Linnaeus), family Ericaceae, commonly is called marsh rosemary, marsh tea, or marsh Labrador tea. It is a fragrant woody evergreen small shrub (up to 1 m in height), distributed in northern and central Europe, northern parts of Asia, and North America. Rh. tomentosum H. is a perennial plant, growing in a peaty soil and forming colonies. The plant known under the name Devilâ€™s Broom growth throughout all the territory of Lithuania: in marshes, coniferous forests, peat bogs, and in the sandy pine forests on the Baltic seashore.
